contentrichtext.text: '''Yuliy Sergeievitch Meitus''' (b. {{OldStyleDate|28 January|1903|15 January}} in [[Elisavetgrad]] – 2 April 1997 in [[Kiev]]), was a distinguished [[Ukrainians|Ukrainian]] [[composer]], considered the founder of the Ukrainian Soviet opera. His early style was modernistic, later he used more traditional neo-Romantic idioms.<ref name=Biografija>{{cite web|last=Biografija|title=Мейтус Юлий Сергеевич|url=http://www.biografija.ru/show_bio.aspx?id=86433|publisher=Biografija.ru|accessdate=1 July 2012}} {{ru icon}}</ref> Meitus was born to a Jewish family. In 1919 he graduated from the School of Music in piano from [[Heinrich Neuhaus]], and from the [[National University of Theatre, Film and TV in Kiev|Kharkov Institute of Music and Drama]] in the composition class of C. Bogatyrenko in 1931. During [[World War II]] he was evacuated to the [[Turkmenistan|Turkmen SSR]], where he wrote the first [[Turkmen language|Turkmen]] [[opera]]. Meitus made his debut in film in 1932. He is famous for his 18 [[operas]], a number of orchestral works and about 300 songs on Ukrainian and Russian classical poems,<ref name=Kino-teatr>{{cite web|last=Kino-teatr|title=Мейтус Юлий Сергеевич|url=http://www.kino-teatr.ru/kino/composer/sov/28214/bio/|publisher=Kino-teatr.ru|accessdate=1 July 2012}} {{ru icon}}</ref> among them ''Stolen Happiness,'' the epic ''Yaroslav the Wise,'' ''Daughter of the wind,'' ''Leila and Majnun,'' ''Young Guard,'' and ''Abakan.'' He was buried in the [[Baikove Cemetery]]. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://zn.ua/SOCIETY/yuliy_meytus__vozvraschenie__v_rodnoy_gorod-49948.html Юлий Мейтус — возвращение в родной город] on ZN,UA {{ru icon}} {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Meitus, Yuliy | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = Classical composer | DATE OF BIRTH = 1903 | PLACE OF BIRTH = Elisavetgrad | DATE OF DEATH = 1997 | PLACE OF DEATH = Kiev }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Meitus, Yuliy}} [[Category:1903 births]] [[Category:1997 deaths]] [[Category:People from Kirovohrad]] [[Category:Ukrainian composers]] [[Category:Recipients of the Shevchenko National Prize]] {{Ukraine-bio-stub}}
